stories.title: A Face Search Engine Anyone Can Use Is Alarmingly Accurate
Why is the Python environment so f*ucking fragile, and why do we tolerate this?

stories.text:
It's 2022, torrent technology has been around for 15+ years.

So why is it still not trivial to host a file by torrent on a private network? If I have a set of machines behind a firewall, it is a huge pain to setup a qbittorrent instance and configure clients to use it, and even once that is setup the retrieval process is nothing like "wget magnet://...".

To be clear, projects like aria2 (C++) and webtorrent (nodejs) do exist, but try to seriously use them and you'll find they are slow to get started and overall unreliable.
stories.title: Ask HN: Why isn't is possible to easily host a file over torrent?
Guarding Against Physical Attacks: The Xbox One Story

stories.text:
Over the past week I built a project to let people self-host an entire maps stack so they don't have to send data to the big G. Right now it includes a base map, geocoder and directions server. Currently only bicycle directions are supported, and I'm only hosting tiles for Seattle because I'm unemployed and can't afford to host data for the whole planet. Check it out!

https://maps.ellenhp.me/

https://github.com/ellenhp/headway

Ultimately I'd like to really focus on transit routing (not implemented) but I'll probably throw a driving mode in there too.
stories.title: Show HN: Self-Hosted Maps Stack

stories.text:
As a community, tech expects documentation to be 'up to date'. Maybe books will be more like this in the future?

By way of example: I'd like to see a continually updated book on climate change, that is both an in depth look at where we are and where we think we're going (new tech, etc). Wikipedia is something like this, but it's not linear, and that format is really helpful for onboarding people to ideas without assuming a lot of background knowledge.
stories.title: Ask HN: What are continually updated books you'd like to see?
